Road to 2012 - Transcript for Nathan Stephens
Interview Cardiff 18.5.10

5.text:
I'm Nathan Stephens, double Paralympian, competed
in both winter and summer, competed in sledge

9.text:
hockey in Turin 2006 and shot put, javelin
and discus in Beijing 2008.

14.text:
I’ve always been quite a sporty person,
at the age of 6,7 to 8 I was well into my

21.text:
rugby and football playing in the local team.
But when I lost my legs at age 9, it felt

29.text:
that it all got taken away from me then, it
all happened so suddenly, and I thought I'd

34.text:
never be able to take sport up again. I got
myself back into sport with the help from

38.text:
my parents, brother and all the friends I
had in school, I just cracked on with life.

43.text:
You've only got one life at the end of the
day and you have to live it to its maximum.

47.text:
0'50 The Sledge Hockey Team
We made it to the Paralympics, which none

52.text:
of us thought we'd ever do, we beat Italy
the home nation in the final, which was 7th,

57.text:
8th place final and I scored the winning goal,
which was like 'yes thank you!' which topped

63.text:
off my winter Olympics experience. I was only
17 and thought that was the biggest stage

70.text:
I could ever possibly get to. After I got
back from Turin I had the option to continue

74.text:
with sledge hockey or convert to athletics
full time, when I got told by my athletics

81.text:
coach that you could be great at this if you
put your mind to it, settle down to it, do

87.text:
it full time, you can go all the way.
1'33 Going Solo

93.text:
I found it hard to adapt, and when I went
into athletics and you are an individual;

97.text:
I'm used to having twenty guys around all
having the same emotions. Anthony Hews Has

104.text:
been my coach now for seven years, I've grown
with him and he's grown with me, he's learnt

108.text:
stuff off me that he didn't know before, we've
grown together. Every step you take, they

114.text:
take. Every down day you have, they have.
Every good performance you celebrate, they

120.text:
are going to celebrate it with you. There's
got to be that relationship between you and

124.text:
your coach, there's got to be that chemistry.
You could almost say that we are best friends,

129.text:
because if I've got a problem I know I can
go to him and he will the first one to sort

133.text:
it out.
If I can tell my story and inspire other people

136.text:
to do the same, inspire young disabled athletes
to go out there and achieve their goals and

142.text:
chase their dreams, then it's brilliant.
2'28 Beijing 2008

148.text:
It never actually hit me that I had qualified
for Beijing until I got to the stadium, got

154.text:
to the opening ceremony and you're surrounded
by 94000 people all screaming, you get into

159.text:
that atmosphere into the zone, you're starstruck,
you can’t believe you’ve actually made

167.text:
it. It was a fantastic experience, one of
the best experiences of my life.

175.text:
Went out there to compete and finished fourth,
I was in third medal place for a half of the

182.text:
competition and the three big guys came out
and knocked me back. I think it was a nice

189.text:
step in the door, to say 'Look I’m here,
you'd better watch out next time.'

193.text:
Coming up now to London 2012 now with the
GB athletes, we're doing this for Britain,

198.text:
we're doing this for our nation. If we can
all grasp that goal, come together as a team,

205.text:
create that team moral that we all need, because
at the end of the day, we're all going out

208.text:
there as Great Britain, and we all want to
win.

213.text:
Not many people say they've competed in a
home Olympics or Paralympics, but to come

217.text:
home with the medal or to stay home with the
medal, and keep it in Britain would be absolutely

223.text: fantastic. It would be the dream.
